Award.AwardTitle: DataNet Full Proposal: DataNet Federation Consortium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Major science and engineering initiatives are dependent upon massive data collections that comprise observational data, experimental data, simulation data, and engineering data. To support science and engineering collaborations, a policy driven national data management infrastructure will be implemented. The implementation prototype will address both the life cycle of science and engineering data and the sustainability of data collections and repositories over time, across changes in technology and changes in usage. The motivation for building the national infrastructure comes from the data management requirements of the NSF Ocean Observatories Initiative (real-time data streams, simulation output, video), the NSF Consortium of Universities for Advancement of Hydrologic Science (point data), engineering projects in education and CAD/CAM/CAE archives, the iPlant collaborative (genome databases), the Odum social science institute (statistics), and the NSF Science of Learning Centers (EEG / MRI sensor data, video).

The approach is based on a bottom-up federation of existing data management systems through use of the integrated Rule-Oriented Data System (iRODS). Each of the referenced national initiatives has implemented a core data management system based upon the iRODS data grid technology. Through federation, the independent systems can be assembled into a national data infrastructure that integrates collections across project-specific technology (such as real-time sensor data acquisition systems), institutional repositories, regional data grids, federal repositories, and international data grids. The resulting infrastructure will enable collaborative research among researchers in academic institutions and federal agencies, and across national boundaries.

Evolution of the policies (computer actionable rules) and procedures (computer executable workflows) that govern each stage of the data life cycle will be supported. Specific policies and procedures will be implemented for each domain to support their community standards for managing data in their local data grid. The project will develop the interoperability mechanisms required to share data between the domains, develop sets of policies and procedures to govern the data life cycle stages, and develop policies and procedures that enable re-use of collections. The national data management infrastructure will demonstrate enforcement of data management policies that comply with NSF Data management and preservation requirements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The emergence of massive data collections has ushered a paradigm shift in the way scientific research is conducted and new knowledge is discovered. Traditional observe-hypothesis-test model of small-scale scientific endeavor is increasingly augmented and in some cases supplanted with collaborative scientific research applying complex patterns of data integration and analysis involving multi-disciplinary teams from distributed organizations brought together to solve common problems. The aim of the DataNet Federation Consortium (DFC) project is to harness the power of data and computation in collaborative environments, through the design and implementation of an evolutionary platform seamlessly mediating the interplay between data, computation and scientists.

The DFC project implements a collaboration framework promoting sharing in and across multiple Science and Engineering disciplines.  The chief outcome of DFC is a policy-oriented federation platform that intertwines human interactions, through policy sets, with evolving cyberinfrastructure, leading to a system that has proven to be extensible, sustainable and applicable across multiple disciplines. The guiding vision of the DFC is rooted in four principles for collaboration:

1.  Develop scientific collaboration environments, applying policy-based concepts in publication, sharing, and preservation of discipline-centric metadata-based discovery products;

2.  Establish National Data Cyberinfrastructure, showing feasibility through usage and co-ordination across six science and engineering disciplines through federation of systems;

3.  Support  live research data, by provisioning access to multi-disciplinary data from national-scale projects;

4.  Support reproducible data-driven research, enabling sustainability of research through reuse and repurposing of workflows, tools and procedures. DFC recognizes the need for sharing workflows and procedures, capturing provenance, and providing reuse.

The strength and depth of this vision has been proven by its resilience even with the rapid changes in technology that have happened over the past 8 years since the first proposal for DFC was made to NSF.  We believe that these principles are fundamental to every scientific collaboration infrastructure of the future. DFC realized this vision in collaboration research through sharing of data and workflows across a federated network.  By sharing data, researchers broaden the application of observational, experimental and simulation datasets gathered for one project through reuse and repurpose.  By sharing workflows, researchers can implement reproducible data-driven research and enable application of software tools across disciplines. DFC enabled creation of new modalities for data life-cycle management, seamlessly integrated with computational analyses and supporting registration and sharing of workflow analytics.  Policy sets allow creation of trusted life-cycle management of workflow and data for storing, sharing and curation.  DFC enabled integration of third-party service layers, including DataNet partners, DIBBS projects and other national NSF research initiatives (eg. CyVerse and HydroShare).   DFC enables execution of scientific workflows on NSF HPC infrastructures (eg. XSEDE) and cloud platforms (eg. AmazonAWS and MicrosoftAzure).

Intellectual Merit: Realization of the four principles required integration of novel policy-based organization with an evolutionary software architecture. DFC meshed three core platform concepts:  virtualization, policy-driven automations, and federation, which provide the extensibility, sustainability and technology independence needed for long-term collaboration. The DFC project extended virtualization beyond data to encompass micro-services and workflows as realizable objects and extended the concept of federation through two new models – loosely coupled federation and asynchronous federation. The DFC collaboration structure captures user interactions as policies and automates their application in the software platform.

Policies are central to DFC and controls cyberinfrastructure through a social consensus. Policies govern data and workflow life-cycle management and the sharing of data and services within and across disciplinary boundaries. Using the proven iRODS software, policies are translated into machine-actionable rules. Policy enforcement is supported by an integrated metadata framework that capture the states of policy execution. Policies enable checking conformance, task automation, product creation, trust establishment, controlled sharing, reaction to contingencies and tracking provenance. Policies relieve scientists the burden of managing complex data-oriented interactions.

Broad Impact: The virtualization, policy and federation mechanisms have been applied in large-scale projects across multiple disciplines. Over the past four years, hydrologists and cognitive scientists, social and marine scientists, biologists and engineering students have utilized the generic DFC federation platform to enable, enhance and ease their scientific tasks. They have launched workflows in the large, computing in the cloud as well as on NSF’s super computing platforms. They have applied and shared complex workflows that harnessed large-scale data from local storage, institutional repositories, federal data resources, sensor networks, and the cloud. They have simplified large-scale distributed data management through policy automation and they have applied discipline-centric policies to enhance data sharing.  

One of the main outcomes of the DFC Project is the sustainability of the iRODS middleware and the extensions done through the DFC Platform. The creation of the iRODS Consortium (https://irods.org/about/) supports further development of the software, encourages the growth of the user and developer communities and facilitates support, education, and collaboration opportunities.  Through the efforts of the DFC project, the iRODS Consortium has graduated into a vibrant and sustainable ecosystem.
